¬°Campanas del Infierno! ¬°Esto es un caf√©! ¬°¬°¬°¬°He dicho T√âEEE!!!!... ¬°He dicho! ¬°T√∫! ¬°Bienvenido al tutorial de Mount&Blade: Napoleonic Wars, my buen hombre!^Ahora, para empezar tu entrenamiento, utiliza las teclas 'WASD' para andar hasta la posici√≥n indicada por la flecha. Puedes utilizar el rat√≥n para mirar a tu alrededor, ¬°mejor para identificar los Franceses, ¬øEh?! ¬°Bleeehaha!
¬øVes esa pieza de gloriosa ingenier√≠a Brit√°nica en frente de ti? ¬°Mira al mosquete y presiona 'F' para cogerlo!

¬°Maravilloso! ¬°Ahora est√°s armado, Se√±or! Vamos a hacer algo de da√±o a esos objetivos en frente de ti.^Presiona el bot√≥n izquierdo del rat√≥n para apuntar con el mosquete, y utiliza el rat√≥n para cambiar la direcci√≥n en la que apuntas. N√≥tese que los mosquetes son algo impredecibles, o m√°s bien terriblemente imprecisos. ¬°Bleahaha!^Una vez seas feliz con tu punter√≠a, puedes proceder a soltar el bot√≥n izquierdo del rat√≥n para disparar.

¬°Mala suerte! Parace que no has dado en el objetivo. Es hora de recargar tu arma y volver a intentarlo.^Para recargar, haz click con el bot√≥n izquierdo del rat√≥n y espera a que tu personaje termina de recargar. Le costar√° un par de segundos, por lo que se paciente. Recurda que no puedes moverte mientras recargas.^Una vez hayas terminado de recargar, vuelve a intentar a disparar a tu objetivo. No te preocupes si fallas, siempre puedes volver a recargar y reintentarlo.

¬°Muy bien, Se√±or! Ahora, si lo deseas, puedes seguir practicando;^ en otro caso, si sientes que ya controlas el disparo, puedes moverte a la siguiente √°rea a la izquierda, donde la flecha est√° apuntando.

¬°Muy bien, Se√±or! Si lo deseas, Se√±or, puedes recargar tu arma y volver a disparar.^Para recargar, haz click con el bot√≥n izquierdo del rat√≥n y espera a que tu personaje termina de recargar. Le costar√° un par de segundos, por lo que se paciente. Recurda que no puedes moverte mientras recargas.^Una vez sientas que ya controlas el disparo, puedes moverte a la siguiente √°rea a la izquierda, donde la flecha est√° apuntando..

Hay momentos en la batalla en la que es preferible estar cerca y personal con el viejo Franc√©s, raz√≥n por la cual tu mosquete est√° equipado con una bayoneta.^Sin embargo, tu mosquete est√° actualmente en 'modo de disparo'; para utilizar la bayoneta debes cambiar a 'modo de combate cuerpo a cuerpo'. El bot√≥n para cambiar entre uno y otro modo es 'X'. Presi√≥nalo ahora.

Excelente. Ahora estas en modo de combate y preparado para cargar contra esos mu√±ecos de entrenamiento con tu bayoneta.^¬°PERO! Antes de hacer eso, hay otro asunto importante que deber√≠as conocer.^No tienes por qu√© estar de pie continuamente, puedes tambi√©n agacharte. Presiona 'Z' para hacerlo.

¬°Bien! Como puedes ver ahora te est√°s agachando. Dado que tambi√©n est√°s en 'modo de combate', puedes ver que tu personaje est√° apuntalando su bayoneta. Esto es muy efectivo contra ataques frontales de infanter√≠a.^Lev√°ntate y contin√∫a. Para hacerlo, presiona 'Z' otra vez o simplemente cualquiera de las teclas de movimiento.

Ahora, en cuanto a atacar y defender. Para atacar, presiona el bot√≥n izquierdo del rat√≥n mientras mueves el rat√≥n en la direcci√≥n en la que deseas atacar. Tu bayoneta s√≥lo tiene dos direcciones: arriba y abajo. Otras armas pueden tener otras direcciones. Por ejemplo, las espadas tienen cuatro: arriba, abajo, izquierda y derecha. Para realizar tu ataque, suelta el bot√≥n izquierdo del rat√≥n. ^La defensa funciona de forma similar. Presiona el bot√≥n derecho del rat√≥n mientras mueves el rat√≥n en la direcci√≥n que deseas bloquear. Cerci√≥rate de que est√°s bloqueando el ataque de tu enemigo en la direcci√≥n adecuada, o las ranas te har√°n un trabajo r√°pido.^Ahora practica con tu bayoneta destrozando todos los mu√±ecos en el √°rea.

Ahora que controlas lo b√°sico del combate de infanter√≠a, empezaremos con la caballer√≠a.^Te ha sido dado un refinado equipamiento y un magn√≠fico caballo. Para montar dicho caballo, anda hasta √©l y presiona 'F'.

¬øAs√≠ que has montado? Excelente. Para moverte montado seguir√°s utilizando las teclas 'WASD', pero los principios de movimiento son algo diferentes: 'W' incrementar√° tu velocidad y 'S' la disminuir√°; 'A' y 'D' har√°n girar a tu caballo. Moviendo el rat√≥n puedes mirar a tu alrededor - pero hacerlo no har√° girar autom√°ticamente a tu caballo. Int√©ntalo ahora para moverte donde apunta la flecha.

¬°Maravilloso! Ahora para tu caballo. Es momento de realizar algunos disparos desde el caballo. ¬øVes esos objetos en la distancia? Disparar sobre un caballo es muy similar a hacerlo a pie, por lo que utiliza lo que has aprendido para golpear a cualquiera de esos objetivos.

¬°Por el infierno y los perdigones! ¬°Has fallado! No te preocupes, puedes recargar y volver a intentarlo, just como antes. Pero recuerda, la regla de que no puedes moverte mientras recargas sigue contando a caballo. Puedes volver a intentarlo, una vez hayas terminado de recargar.

¬°Lo has conseguido! Puedes continuar practicando, si lo deseas.^^Una vez est√©s preparado para continuar, trataremos las bases del combate a caballo. Necesitar√°s una espada para esto. Para cambiar tu arma a la espada, gira la rueda del rat√≥n hacia arriba.

¬°Bravo! Puedes continuar practicando, si lo deseas. Recuerda, la regla de que no puedes moverte mientras recargas sigue contando a caballo.^^Una vez est√©s preparado para continuar, trataremos las bases del combate a caballo. Necesitar√°s una espada para esto. Para cambiar tu arma a la espada, gira la rueda del rat√≥n hacia arriba.

De la misma forma que el disparo, el combate a caballo es similar a luchar a pie. Cabalga alrededor de los mu√±ecos y destr√∫yelos.^Intenta golpearles mientras mantienes el movimiento, pues estar quieto te quita la ventaja de velocidad y maniobravilidad. Si sincronizas bien tus golpes, puedes golpear a tu enemigo y estar lejos antes de que el sinverg√ºenza se de cuenta de que est√° muerto.
¬°Espl√©ndido! Ahora ya conoces los aspectos m√°s importantes del combate a caballo.

¬°Por fin! Es tiempo de entrenar con la artiller√≠a.^Anda hasta el ca√±√≥n y coge algo de munici√≥n de la caja.^^Hay tres tipos de munici√≥n:^La bola de ca√±√≥n es multiprop√≥sito y especialmente √∫til contra edificios;^La metralla matar√° a cualquier en frente del ca√±√≥n, pero es notablemente inefectiva a la hora de dar a objetivos a larga distancia;^Los obuses son extremedamente efectivos contra tropas enemigas, ya que explotan soltando fragmentos de metal en todas las direcciones. Sin embargo, no est√°n disponibles para los ca√±ones est√°ndar.
Pon la munici√≥n en el ca√±√≥n desde el frente. Para hacerlo, mira al frontal del ca√±√≥n, y cuando veas el texto 'Colocar Munici√≥n', presiona 'F' hasta que la barra llegue hasta el final.
Ahora tienes que usar la baqueta para recargar el ca√±√≥n. Otra vez, mira al frente del ca√±√≥n y mant√©n 'F' hasta acabar.
Antes de disparar, querr√°s mover el ca√±√≥n hacia adelante. Para hacerlo, mira hacia √©l y presiona 'F'.
Finalmente, mira a la parte de atr√°s del ca√±√≥n hasta que veas el mensaje 'Tomar Control'. Entonces presiona 'F' para tomar el control del ca√±√≥n.

¬°Ahora controlas el ca√±√≥n, Se√±or! Otra vez, utiliza el rat√≥n para apuntar. Presionar el bot√≥n izquierdo del rat√≥n har√° que el ca√±√≥n dispare, y el bot√≥n derecho cancelar√° el control, pero por ahora, presiona el bot√≥n izquierdo para disparar.

Este es el fin del tutorial. Ya conoces las bases para combatir en Mount&Blade: Napoleonic Wars. Presiona 'Tab' para dejar este tutorial cuando est√©s preparado.^^¬°Buena suerte en el campo de batalla, Se√±or! ¬°Despedido por el t√© y los bollos!
The Danube River, the second longest in Europe, divides the Austrian Empire in two. ^Following their failure in the Ulm campaign, the Austrian Army is retreating across the river at Vienna.
The French advance guard, however, is not far behind. ^All other bridges being destroyed, the crossing at Vienna is vital for the French.

Should the Austrians notice a French attempt at crossing they will blow up the bridge. ^If they succeed, the French will be unable to pursue the retreating allied army and the victory at Ulm will be for nothing.
As such the French marshals, Murat and Lannes, are in a though spot; ^They need to get across the bridge without the Austrians noticing.
To do so, they have decided to deploy a ruse: ^Murat and Lannes will attempt to convince the Austrians that a truce has already been signed.
Meanwhile, you will have to silently clear the bridge so the army can cross...
You arrive at the battlefield near the village of Sokolnitz. ^Scouts report the Russians have captured the village and you are to retake it.
Messenger: 'The Russians have capture the village! It is vital that you retake it!'
It would seem the battle is closer than we thought. ^Very well then, retake the village from the Russians!
The village is back under French control, well done! ^But the Russians are already sending soldiers to recapture it, make sure they won't succeed.
You have successfully defended the village form the enemy. ^This will greatly help us on our path to victory!
Messenger: 'The general has heard of your great success in capturing and holding the village ^You'd better go and tell the Emperor himself of these good news!
The City of Dresden, Capitol of Saxony. ^The city is under heavy attack by Coalition forces and you have to help saving it.
The Russians have already taken the walls and more of them are preparing an assault on the gates. ^Your orders are to clear the walls while your allies move and hold the gates.
The walls are safe for now, but the threat to the city is not yet averted. ^Your allies by the gate can't hold out much longer, you need to help them!
The first assault has been broken down, but the enemy is already sending more men to attack. ^You must not let them get past the gate again!
The Russian attack lines are growing thinner and the pressure on the walls are easying. ^The general have been able to spare some men to support you.
The assault has come to a stop and the enemy are in disarray. ^Use this oportunity to sally out and drive the enemy away from the city!
While the defense of the city was a success, the outlying farms and villages are still in enemy hands. ^Your orders are to liberate this village from Austrian control.
But to do so, you must first clear the area of any Austrians still out in the open. ^Scout report that there is a group of four companies ahead of your position.

Unfortunatly they have already noticed your dragoons and have formed squares to face the threat. ^This will be a though fight, as your infantry and artillery are still way behind and cannot support you.
But it seems that the Austrian commander have ventured a bit too far from his troops! ^If you can capture him, his men might lose heart and the figthing ahead will be easier...
The squares have been defeated, but the enemy still holds the village. ^It is time to attack and capture it.
Luckily more cavalry is arriving to support you. ^Use it well and victory will be ours. En avant!

December 1, 1805^It was a fine respite, but now we march once again. Praise God this will be our final effort! ^It is said that we shall march directly into the battle.^^Our time on the outskirts of Vienna was surely the finest days of the campaign. Rich villages ^with large, clean houses, wonderful food and wine -- and of course the pretty girls all helped us ^replenish our energies.^We had been shaken by the endless marches through terrible weather. Exhausted by our pursuit ^of the retreating Allied forces. It was good to forget, for a little while.^^But our peaceful rest ended abruptly; we received the order to rejoin the main army as quickly as ^possible, and now we march madly to battle once more. In a forced march we have left nearly half ^of the regiment behind, but general Friant is determined to arrive to the battlefield on time, ^and will not pause for our supporting forces to rejoin us.^^The Allies are said to greatly outnumber our own troops, especially in cavalry. It seems that the ^battle will be defensive this time, but the situation remains unclear. A messenger from the Emperors ^headquarters informed us, as he rode past our column, that our rear guard had been driven back ^near a place called Vishau, and were retreating towards Austerlitz^^I dare not speak of it, but thoughts of the upcoming battle fill me with terror. Marengo was the last ^Well, I should say the only large battle I took part in, and this was almost 5 years ago. I still ^remember the horrible things I saw that day; it makes my body shake to think of it. ^Luckily, I have been able to conceal my feelings thus far; ^our men despise cowardice, and treat it as treason.

December 1, 1805^It was a fine respite, but now we march once again. Praise God this will be our final effort! ^It is said that we shall march directly into the battle.^^Our time on the outskirts of Vienna was surely the finest days of the campaign. Rich villages ^with large, clean houses, wonderful food and wine -- and of course the pretty girls all helped us ^replenish our energies.^We had been shaken by the endless marches through terrible weather. Exhausted by our pursuit ^of the retreating Allied forces. It was good to forget, for a little while.^^But our peaceful rest ended abruptly; we received the order to rejoin the main army as quickly as ^possible, and now we march madly to battle once more. In a forced march we have left nearly half ^of the regiment behind, but general Friant is determined to arrive to the battlefield on time, ^and will not pause for our supporting forces to rejoin us.^^The Allies are said to greatly outnumber our own troops, especially in cavalry. It seems that the ^battle will be defensive this time, but the situation remains unclear. A messenger from the Emperors ^headquarters informed us, as he rode past our column, that our rear guard had been driven back ^near a place called Vishau, and were retreating towards Austerlitz^^I dare not speak of it, but thoughts of the upcoming battle fill me with terror. Marengo was the last ^Well, I should say the only large battle I took part in, and this was almost 5 years ago. I still ^remember the horrible things I saw that day; it makes my body shake to think of it. ^Luckily, I have been able to conceal my feelings thus far; ^our men despise cowardice, and treat it as treason.

August 26, 1813^We are preparing to march on Drezden, where our small garrison was formerly besieged by the far ^superior forces of the Allies. Artillery fire is reported to be so powerful that window glass ^shakes even 10 kilometers from the city.^^The original plan was to raid and disrupt Allied communications, ^but the Emperor revised his plan two days ago when he learned of a threat on the Saxon capital. ^When he discovered the scale of the threat, he sent us to save the city, while the bulk of his ^forces proceeded with General Vandamme to continue with the raid as originally planned.^It is no surprise that the Allied forces will attempt to seize Dresden. Its defenses are miserable, ^and the garrison is quite insufficient. But Napoleon intends to give the Allies an unpleasant ^surprise of their own, for the Allies are not scouting anywhere near the area that we are approaching from.^^We have a strong force, and numerous cavalry guided by Prince Murat himself. Unfortunately, ^the weather seems to be getting worse and worse, and it probably will be raining by the time ^we reach Dresden. Under such circumstances, the benefits we might reap from our superior cavalry ^will significantly decrease.^^Myself, I welcome the battle. Finally we may take our revenge upon the Russians, for what we have ^suffered these past six months. I have tried to forget what horrors we witnessed on the way from ^Moscow to Berezina, but the images still come unbidden to my mind. These nightmares shall likely ^pursue me to the end of my days. ^We must win this battle, and this war, that our comrades shall not have died in vain.

September 5, 1812^^I grow tired of this war. The march has been tolerable, but the past few days were difficult, ^and I am only now recovering from an illness. Blast, the climate is terrible! Scorching hot days, ^cold nights, dry air. There are no more Russian peasants to be seen. They‚Äôve burned their houses and fled, ^leaving little to sustain us on the long march towards Moscow.^^Our men grow tired as well. For too long, they have been biting at the heels of a fleeing enemy. ^But they are cheerful that the march is nearing its end, and gladly greet the coming battle. ^We call the Russians cowards, and imagine a swift victory, that we may return to the arms of our loved ones. ^Our soldiers even ask permission to wear parade uniforms into the battle. Our hopes and weariness have ^blinded us: the men do not see that the most difficult challenge is yet to come.^^Meanwhile, the Russian soldiers have halted their retreat, and instead are digging in for the final stand.^^Their preparations are covered by a great redoubt at Shevardino. It is well away from their rear positions, ^which makes it a fine target. Marshall Davout has received orders to capture the redoubt as quickly as ^possible. I am to join the troops of General Compans in this attack, to ensure that everything goes as planned.^^But I am wary. Never before have I seen such fortifications! I have grown certain that these Russians ^are no cowards. ^They will retreat no further, but will defend their Moscow to the dying breath.
